The model is a work in progress and not well optimized, but it produced a passable print.

This model wasn't originally designed for 3d printing, so it's not really optimized, but I wanted to try it out to learn where my new printer (and this model) would fail. It was more successful than I imagined so i figured I'd share it.  
I printed this in ABS and 0.1mm resolution and used full support

Feature Bench

This is just a simple switch panel I made for my boat. Most boats have these items installed so I got these waterproof switches from amazon.com http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00RZ4WEIA/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 This panel is 4 mm thick and I filled it 10% with a standard wall it seems plenty strong and the switches snap in perfectly. Or if you have other switches you can resize the holes ofc. The words file is just to designate the items I intend the switches to activate but b/c they are a separate file you can ofc change, rearrange, or delete them all together and still print the panel.

I have a dual extruder printer so I opened the base file and positioned it on my build platform.  Then I opened the word file and elevated it by 4mm above the build platform b/c thats the height of the base piece.  Then I positioned it accordingly relative to the switches.  That way I could print in two colors.  You can combine this however you like.  
I printed it with a 10% fill with a standard boarder it seems plenty strong.  Enjoy.

comments.author: b3nladen

comments.text: It was very simple.  I used the Import feature in Tinkercad.  If you haven't used Tinkercad, it's a web-based 3D modeling system that's free to use.  Download the stl file from Thingiverse, import it into Tinkercad, and then start modifying away.  Import will bring the entire object in as a single component, you won't be able to break it down (ungroup), but you can modify the design by adding shapes to it (or adding holes).  If you publish the result be sure to note that it's a remix of the original stl thing.  Good luck!

description.text: This is an exhaust fitting I developed for my Lulzbot Taz 4 or 5 printer enclosure, but it could be used for any kind of exhaust needs. (see thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:746922) It is designed to mount to a 50x50mm dc fan, and screw into 2.5" exhaust hose from McMaster-Carr: http://www.mcmaster.com/#5398k12/=wjk94g This fitting threads into the non-flared end of the hose, and provides mounting to the fan and enclosure outlet port. Update 12-6-2015 Check out the wall mount version of this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1178146

I printed this with 2 shells, 40% infill. Depending on how you mount this fitting it could see a lot of stress. The exhaust hose it is designed for is heavy. So depending on your application, you might consider 100% infill.  
When printing in ABS you should scale it up 1.01 in X and Y and 1.005 in Z to account for shrinkage.

author: taxpon

title: Motor Case for Mabuchi 775, Ryobi saw motor

description.text:
If you are looking for a very high torque small electric motor, this is a very inexpensive setup. Turns out the Ryobi R10633, 18V, 5 1/2" trim saw has a Mabuchi RS-775WC-8514, you can pick the Ryobi saws up used on ebay for 20-25 dollars. These motors sell for 50-70 bucks new without the gear box. Use the gear box and motor case that comes with the saw with this 3D printed case. The Ryobi gear case has a very strong 9-42 tooth gears in it. The Ryobi output shaft is 10mm and will take a 3/4" OD flexible shaft coupler or 10mm ServoCity set screw hub. There is a nice big 10x26x5 6000Z ball bearing in the gear case output shaft you can use in the 3D printed case.
The Mabuchi RS-775 motor puts out 1561 g-cm of torque at 17040RPM at 18Volts. That is 5 times the torque of a RS540 motors 312 g-cm. The RS-775 motor will work on voltage from 6-20 volts. The Ryobi gear reduction cuts the RPM down to 3651 and ups the torque to 7285 g-cm. Gear it down from there and you have a motor that will run about anything. Here are the specs on the Mabuchi motor http://www.mabuchi-motor.co.jp/cgi-bin/catalog/e_catalog.cgi?CAT_ID=rs_775vcwc
In one of the pictures you can see the difference in the motors. That is a 370 motor on the right, a RS-540 Mabuchi and 550 Titan motor in the center and the RS775 on the left. The RS775 is huge!
Use 8x3/4" sheet metal screws to attach Ryobi case to the 3D printed case. There are two gear cases one to mount up from the bottom and one to mount up from the output shaft side. The bottom mount has a 2 1/2" x 5/8" bolt pattern on bottom.
Was going to use these gear boxes to run a large scale 1/6th Cat RC bulldozer I am making, but the Ryobi gears where to large to fit in the dozer. Used the motors but had to design my own gear box for the RS775. These motors are brutes, very powerful running them at 12V, 18V would be very interesting.
One drawback is this motor takes 18.7 amps to run it, you will need a pretty heavy duty 20-30 amp motor speed controller to control the motors speed in a robot or RC vehicle.
Please use caution around children. As with any gear drive or belt drive, (If you ever want to play the guitar) never ever, ever get your fingers close to the pinch point of gears (especially this one), belts or spinning saw blades. Make sure you hold on tight or mount the RS775 motor before starting it, this motor makes some serious torque. Have fun and be safe!

description.text:
I needed a way to mount one or more 5015S blower fans to the "Kossel Effector for E3D-v6 Hotend" by tobiaskornmayer. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:402022 Remixed from ChrisT88's "Mini Kossel Adjustable Blower Fan Mounts" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:714282 You will need the Fan Mount Swiwel from that thing to mount the fan in.

remixed_from.author: joem_
remixed_from.title: QI Wireless Charger for Google Nexus 5

title: QI Wireless Charger for Google Nexus 6

description.text: Similar to the QI Wireless Charger for Google Nexus 5 except a bit more stylish and updated for the Nexus 6! I used a single-coil wireless QI charging board from eBay. It came with a little USB socket board that gets fit into the base so the cable can be plugged into the back.

It gets printed on it's side, so rotate before printing.  
I cut the wires for the USB socket board, then slid it in from the back side, trimmed the wires down and re-soldered them to the circuit board - I could have just cut and reattach the wires if I didn't want to solder it.  
Then I hot-glued the coil in place and hot-glued the circuit board in place.

remixed_from.author: mojomoney
remixed_from.title: Halo Themed Case For Samsung Captivate

title: Case For Samsung GTI9000 (Galaxy, Captivate etc.)

description.text: The very first idea what to print when I will have a working 3D-Printer was, to substitute my chunky car mount for my Galaxy S GTI9000 Android phone. What I have is a car mount from Gomadic. I like the mechanism to clip it to the air vent and to turn around my phone, but the bracket is quite horrible beside I can only see half the screen of my phone while driving. So I discovered mojomoneys Halo Themed Case For Samsung Captivate http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3828. My idea was to attach a slot to the backside to connect the bracket and the case. Unluckily I realized that the dimensions for switches, microphone and camera on a Captivate are different from a Galaxy. So I decided to adjust it and asked mojomoney for the source files. He posted some SolidWorks files (Thank you!), which I couldn't use because I don't I have this software. So I worked with the .stl file and OpenSCAD. First of all OpenSCAD told me, that this .stl isn't a manifold object. So I started to get it manifold. For that I have had to remove all the nice Halo carvings, which mojomoney made :( (Excuse me for that!). But in the very end I got a manifolded object. It doesn't look as nice as mojomoneys, the holes are all squared and not rounded, but I don't want to carry it around just put it into my car. Also I designed a small slot mechanism which I glued to the backside. I did it that somebody can use the case for other designs. Thanks again mojomoney for your perfect design! I couldn't have done this by my own, I've just two weeks experiences with CAD software (OpenSCAD).

There are three .scad and three .stl files:
One of each for the case without any wholes, just the raw body for scaling it and placing more beautiful wholes to it than I have done
One of each with the squared holes, which fit for the Samsung Galaxy.
And one of each for the slot object.
Maybe you first print a small slice in X an Y direction to be sure that the measurements fit your device. If it is to tight in Y direction just for a few tenth of a millimeters you can remove some small pieces with a knife or you scale it again in your software.
You can put nicer holes to it. If you want to use it as a car mount, just print the slot piece and glue it to the case.  
Print it and do what you like with it!

Here are Kossel corners that use only 2040 extrusions. Useful for cases where your local hardware shop only sells extrusions in 5 meter pieces. It's fairly parametric so there are a couple of things that can be tweaked, such as the extrusion width/thickness, but you might have to play with the variables to get your desired output. Update: A couple of people on #reprap mentioned that putting the towers in this configuration doesn't make full use of the extra width in the 2040 to avoid the top of the tower from twisting against the bottom. The Wolfstock corners might be a better alternative. Update: Added top and bottom corners. The top corner includes a 3mm hole + nut trap for using 623zz bearings on an M3 screw as an idler.

title: Kossel Mini SmartLCD-Case cut up for small printbeds

description.text:
For my first self-built 3d printer, a Kossel mini, I needed an LCD casing and liked this one by schlotzz: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:320117. Unfortunately, I found no LCD casing that could be printed on the Kossel itself -- the designs I found were all too large to fit on the round build area of the Kossel mini. Completely new to 3d printing, I searched for some way to cut this into pieces and found the puzzlecut library (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:35834) by nothinglabs. As there may be more newbies like I am and it took me some time to find out how to cut this, I decided to make this my first thingiverse upload. Hope this helps someone :) As I'm doing this now in some foreign hotel room, I have not printed it yet. All real work done by: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:320117
Please see there for additional information and instructions.

title: (moved) Gearless Follow Focus for Shoulder Rig

description.text:
THIS DESIGN HAS BEEN MOVED TO YOUMAGINE:
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/gearless-follow-focus-for-shoulder-rig Reasons:
http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.de/2014/01/leaving-thingiverse.html

Assembly is trivial.
I don't really need to write anything about that here. ;) This is a very simple follow-focus using a roller-blade or skateboard -wheel instead of gears.
It's great to experiment with a follow focus on a shoulder-rig without investing a lot of time and effort into a more complex geared or even remote follow focus. See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7256 for a much cooler but also more complex design requiring electronics and microcontroller-programming. Update:
I added a (not yet tested) straight version of this follow focus because with my new matte box there was not enough space to mount this anymore. Video:

Another thing I change is the installation part for tuners. Because the things I only could buy in my country - Taiwan, is the regular tuners for guitar, and the printed model is also need to be modified for them. Moreover, I add some icon on the bottom layer but it hard to find. More details about remodeling are written down in Chinese on my blog:
http://lo-chen-note.blogspot.tw/ Also, there is a violin shoulder rest design fit well to this violin.

author: meson-01

description.text:
One shot simple grenade lancer pistol. Added "corpoMK2" and "CorpoMK2Mirrored" with rounded point and mirrored for people without mittor function on slider software. Work in progress
New lock that work better.
New trigger.
Printed and test fired.
It works but the lock is too thin. MK2 body and MK4 barrel printed.
The lock do not work well, to be imrpoved.
I printed by mistake MK1 trigger ant it warks with an unloaded grenade but was too thin to press a charged shell. Fire test: https://youtu.be/nE6Gv2Np_Xg History:
MK2 files with stronger trigger as suggested by csakip. "Canna MK2" added because ABS shrink reduced internal diameter of 1mm! Mk2 barrel has over sized internal and external diameter, I also reduced Z to clear my printer.
If printed in PLA my be MK1 barrel is good. "Canna MK4" added semplified design "GrillettoMK3" added with more travel. Hand grip still missing Thanks http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11748 for the Picatinny rail, it saved lot of drawing time.

It can be printed without support.
"corpo" must be printed 2 times mirroring it. Corpo pinted with 30% infill.
All other with 100% infill. All hinge and nut can be done with 3mm filament.
You need also 2x 5mm springs

This is a model of a simple cubic unit cell showing how only partial atoms are included in the unit cell proper.  The intended purpose of this thing is to use in a chemistry or materials classroom so that students can see the 3-dimensional aspects of the crystal structure.  One possible use of this thing is to print multiples of this model so that they can be stacked to show how unit cells add to generate an extended lattice.
I printed this with 2 shells and a 10% infill with a raft.  It worked perfectly.

author: nicolaeff

description.text: Just a simple render; I don't claim this is going to all fit and work if you print it and I didn't make a channel for the LEDs in the big chicken logo. But... enjoy! Chicken knobs from here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7474 Chicken silhouette from here: http://www.snap2objects.com/2009/06/23/9-free-vector-animal-farm/ Bonus points if you add the sound of a chicken clucking when you turn the knobs!

Here's how I'm getting STUFF like the text and Chicken SVG and text into OpenSCAD: 1) Create STUFF using Inkscape.
2) Make sure to stroke your paths!
3) SAVE AS .PS
4) pstoedit whatever.ps -f dxf file.dxf
5) Open file .dxf in QCad, save as DXF over itself... Import into OpenSCAD! It's a lot of steps, but it works.

description.text:
Hello, Here is a small building game that we can easily take anywhere.
It is the size of a credit card . We can easily store it in her purse or wallet and pull out at any time.
To build this small plane , it just takes a sheet of paper (but it's everywhere ) or cardboard or packaging or a parking ticket .... to make wings. My daughter loves !!! Good print and have fun !!! French before google translation : Bonjour,
Voici un petit jeu de construction qu'on peut facilement emporter partout.
Il a la taille d'une carte de crédit.
On peut le ranger facilement dans son sac ou son portefeuille et le sortir à tout moment.
Pour construire ce petit avion, il faut juste une feuille de papier (mais on en trouve partout) ou de carton ou d'emballage ou un ticket de parking.... pour fabriquer les ailes.
Ma fille adore !!!
Bonne impression et amusez vous !!!

The Pro Trinket interfaces between the two over serial and i2c and ties the samples to the buttons. It's a really slick way to make a compact, all-in-one sound board. This version of the Audio FX Soundboard features a built in amp so you can wire speakers up to terminals or directly on the board. title: Da Vinci 1.0 3D printer filament storage modification + clip

description.text:
UPDATE 07/02/16  Added solid state relay,heat-sink,and 30amp PSU photos.
This is a modification of the Da Vinci 1.0 3D printer, it allows you to store an extra cartridge inside the machine. keeps things tidy and makes it super quick when changing colours.  
Of course this wont make your Da Vinci 1.0 dual extruder but it will free up desk space and uses up the wasted space already inside the printer.  
To change colours You simply go to change cart and swap over from one cart to the other.

Da Vinci 1.0 printer was took apart and i used an heated metal rule to slice through the ABS casing in the area shown.
Part was finished with a flat metal file to make it smooth.

This is a mechanical keyboard with cherry mx switches.It comes with extra keys which is really nice, but there's a lot of cool stuff you could do by 3D printing your own! Read the full guide on: https://learn.adafruit.com/3dprinted-custom-keycaps

comments.text: Is the escape key cap (ada-key.stl) the same size as the alphanumeric key caps?
comments.author: onebeartoe

comments.text: Yes, the Esc key on a typical layout is the same size as the alphanumeric keys. However, when it comes to the curve of the key, it is different. Have a look at a resource like http://support.wasdkeyboards.com/customer/en/portal/articles/1366948-keycap-compatibility for a visual illustration of how keycap size (e.g., 1×1 or 1×1.50) and position/geometry (e.g., R4 vs R2) is denoted.

title: EDIFICIO PEÑA BLANCA en Alicante. PEÑA BLANCA Building, Alicante

description.text:
Edificio proyectado en 1963 por el arquitecto Francisco Muñoz Llorens en la Playa de San Juan en una parcela de 3.900 m2, junto con otro edificio contiguo, con fachada a la Avda. de la Costablanca nº 89 y a la C/Carmelo Simón Plá.
Se trata de dos torres, una con 12 y la otra con 13 plantas.Ambas, se forman a partir de la superposición de paralepípedos alternando su disposición por plantas, lo que provoca un intenso movimiento de fachadas subrayado por el contraste del blanco de los paños y el azul del techo de las terrazas.Muñoz tenía una pequeña obsesión con ligar la pintura con la arquitectura. Tenía admiración por Le Corbusier “Todos los arquitectos de mi época nos sentimos atraídos por la obra de Le Corbusier y las cosas que te gustan siempre terminan por aparecer en lo que haces”. https://www.facebook.com/ANarquitecturaestudio Building designed in 1963 by architect Francisco Muñoz Llores in San Juan Beach (Alicante) (España), on a plot of 3.900 m2, next to an adjoining building with its facades to the Costablanca Avenue, and Carmelo Simón Pla Street.
There are two towers, one with 12 plants, and another with 13. Both are formed from alternating overlapping parallelepipeds by plants , causing an intense movement of facades emphasized by the contrast of white facades and blue ceiling of terraces.
Muñoz had a small obsession with linking the painting and architecture. He had admiration for Le Corbusier " All my time architects felt attracted by the work of Le Corbusier and the things you like always end up appearing in what you do " https://www.facebook.com/ANarquitecturaestudio
http://www.an-arquitectura.es https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zA_GtgUgDJU&feature=youtu.be

author: bryden42

description.text:
First off, I have to say this filament clips are awesome.  I however had problems with the hole size for my 3mm (actually 2.90mm) filament not fitting through the hole.  Ended up having to take a #32 (2.90mm) drill bit and auger out the holes so they'd fit my filament.  BTW, the filament I had fitment problems with these clips was the stuff sold by Aleph Objects, Inc.  The filament they sold is exactly 2.90mm.  
Never had an issue with my prints being inaccurate, so I decided to re-mix this great file with some larger holes.  The clip portion of this is perfect.  
The "Regular" file gives a snug fit.  The "Oversized" has a hole that's 0.1mm larger.  I personally like the oversized file better as I find the filament doesn't need to be THAT tight in the clip.  
Thanks to the original poster of this awesome little file.  Has made my life so much easier in managing my partial spools.  
For those interested, the sample prints shown in the photos were done on a Lulzbot TAZ 5 printer in HIPS using 0.2mm layer height, printed at 240 degrees with a bed temperature of 110 degrees.  Software used to print this was Cura.
A cookie cutter made at the Free Library of Philadelphia's Lilian Marrero Branch.

title: Body Centered Cubic Unit Cell Full Atoms

description.text: This is a model of a body-centered cubic unit cell with full atoms.  The intended purpose of this thing is to use in a chemistry or materials classroom so that students can see the 3-dimensional aspects of the crystal structure.

I printed this with 2 shells and a 10% infill with a raft.  The model includes support structures at local minima that need to be trimmed away after printing (I used wire cutters).  The spheres are well connected by themselves (I put cylinders between them to increase the contact area).

This is a model of a body-centered cubic unit cell showing how partial atoms (as well as one whole atom) are included in the unit cell proper.  The intended purpose of this thing is to use in a chemistry or materials classroom so that students can see the 3-dimensional aspects of the crystal structure.  One possible use of this thing is to print multiples of this model so that they can be stacked to show how unit cells add together to generate an extended lattice.

I printed this with 2 shells and a 10% infill with a raft.  The model includes support structures at local minima that need to be trimmed away after printing (I used wire cutters).  The spheres are well connected by themselves (I put cylinders between them to increase the contact area).

title: Epson Perfection V700 & V750 Kodak Disc Carrier

description.text:
I've been scanning for years now, and the Kodak discs have been a bit of a pain in that positioning them well on the flatbed hasn't been consistent.  
For this purpose I created a carrier for those nasty old Kodak disc negatives such that I can position them consistently in the same place on the scanner each time.  
Hopefully someone else will find this useful for their scanning projects.  
You're going to need a large build platform to print this on.  It's designed to be printed on a Lulzbot TAZ 5 comparably sized print bed.

Nanode - A Network Application Node. Nanode is like an Arduino but with ethernet/web connectivity. It also supports easy to use wireless and wired networks. It has been developed as a low cost tool to allow simple sensor networks to be developed. It's the perfect platform for smart sensors, home automation, monitoring and control. It's through hole construction and the use of socketed DIP ICs makes it easy to build for the home constructor. It's been competetively priced so that it costs about the same as an Arduino (roughly $30 US, or Â£18). Without the ethernet parts it's sub $20 and can be used as a low cost Arduino "work-alike". It's compatible with most Arduino shields. It has some key advantages over the basic Arduino:
  • Built in ethernet controller
  • Unique MAC address ID
  • Supports external EEPROM/FRAM/SRAM/Flash device for increased data storage
  • Supports a simple wireless transceiver shield from Jee Labs.
  • Supports a local multi-drop serial bus for wired networks of Master/Slaves
  • Breadboard friendly I/O connectors bring all I/O out on a 0.1" pitch
    • This is the productionised version of the Nanode for the London Hackspace. It's very much updated and includes a whole lot of new features.

  • SPI serial memory either SRAM, FRAM or EE for storing data and web pages,

  • Microchip MAC chip so that it has a unique MAC address.

  • Wireless Connectivity - plug a Jee Labs RFM12B module straight in to give a bi-directional wireless link.
    • 4.Moves the reset switch to where you can get at it - side actuated
  • Moves the LED to where you can see it.
    • 6.Improved connector for local power/comms bus with 4 pin screw terminal block. Makes for simple interconnection with 4 way telephone cable.

  • Adds the London Hackspace Logo, Pachube Logo and Arbour Wood Ltd details.

  • Adds Auto-reset (from FTDI cable).

  • Adds Virtual USB Vusb (Like Metaboard) for programming http://www.obdev.at/products/vusb/index.html
    http://metalab.at/wiki/Metaboard

EagleCAD schematic and board files included enable this board to be made by pcb fab-house. Zipped Gerbers also included See the Project Wiki Page on the London Hackspace site for more information about this version. http://wiki.hackspace.org.uk/wiki/Project:Nanode

title: Endstop Brackets for the QU-BD Two up

description.text:
These have now been printed and tested for the Z and X Axis. The X axis will also require an additional part that I am going to have to model and make in the next few days so stay tuned for that. These are brackets for endstop switches for the QU-BD Two up 3d printer. These take into account the newer models that are coming with the shaft coupler. You will need the following hardware and modifications in order for these to work. Modifications required:
The X Axis requires either the modification of the part "N" to clear the bolt holding the X Stepper or removing that 4th bolt completely (Bonus of about 15mm build area!) The "Z trigger" will require a #8 screw be drilled into the X Gantry. I had to remove the bottom portion of Part "O" but no structural integrity was lost. (we all know how flimsy the gantry is) Hardware:
Two M3x0.5 x 20mm
Two #8x 1" Screws
3 Endstop switches with 0.75" Mounting holes UPDATES:
03/31/15: Initial Upload and test
04/01/15: List of parts and mods added. Z Trigger Updated to be shorter and allow for better adjustibility

The holes are made to work with the standard endstops that you can buy on Amazon or Ebay.  
The Z trigger is either drilled and screwed to the X gantry or super glued in place.  A #8 bolt and nut is used to change the trigger point.  
The Z backet uses the left 2 most screws on the z stepper motor.  
The X bracket uses the 2 left most screws on the x stepper motor and may need longer M3 bolts.

description.text:
This is the first upgrade I installed on my OneUp. It connects the X-axis carriage to the belt very securely. To my knowledge, it should work for the TwoUp as well. It's modification of the simple_x_carriage_v003 by MarkQV.   
This won't stay on my printer long, but tape wasn't holding everything in place, and while black document clips were secure for the initial prints, I lost too much x-axis range with them.

I printed this with .3mm layer height and 20% honeycomb infill (though I don't know if it needed it).   
After printing, slide between the extruder assembly and the belt, then secure. It is small enough to install without any disassembly.

author: ins

remixed_from.author: twelvepro
remixed_from.title: Prusa i3 Improved for laser cut

description.text:
The plastic parts that came with my i3 frame kit were unusable.  And I wasn't able to print Prusa's original SCAD files from github very well.  My other printer doesn't do long bridges well so I redesigned these parts to eliminate or at least minimize them.   
I was a little concerned about using zip-ties but they seem to work well in holding the X rods and LM8UU bearings. The extruder isn't modified much from the original except for the placement of mounting holes.  I ended up moving them around to get a good fit to the X carriage.  That led to the J-Head slot mount plate's bolt hole placement being asymmetrical.   
The laser cut holes for the Z rods were a bit oversized so I made a pair of supports.  The Z rods are 12.5" versus the original 12" to accommodate them.  Now that I think about it, I could have just printed the top header piece with a clamp built into it.   
The top left X rod support needs to be carved out quite a bit If I intend to use the full volume in the Z axis.  The extruder motor will hit it when it's at or near the zero position in the X axis.  Maybe I should think about making a smaller extruder.

The parts were all printed at .33 mm layer height and 25% infill.  I'll go over a few points about each component group:  
endstops:  The bigger one is for the Z stop.  Use 2 x 12 mm bolts and nuts to attach a switch and 2 x 14 mm bolts and nuts to secure to the Z rod.  I use the smaller bit for my Y endstop.  Run  a zip-tie through the shorter end and secure the block to the Y rod.  Then attach the switch with a zip-tie and wrap around the Z rod.  I don't need the Y to stop very precisely so the ties work great.  
extruder:  The standard Wade's extruder won't mount due to interference between the motor and X rods.  The motor mount is elevated in this design from Prusa's github repository.  I added additional support material in the bearing pocket.  Use  3 x 50 mm bolts to secure to the carriage.  I know.  That's some long bolts.  
extruder_gears:  It's my biohazard gear (thing:53103) with a proper hex depth.  The conical piece is used as a spacer between the spur gear and bearing.  It replaces the 3~4 washers you'd normally use.  Put the wider side against the spur gear.  Print the washer/shim to whatever thickness you need to align the hobbed bolt properly.  The gear ratio's higher than the standard Wade's at 43/13 but it doesn't stress my stepper motor at all.  
hotend_fan_mount:  Use 3 mm nuts and bolts to secure a 40 mm fan and 3 x 15 mm bolt to attach a J-head to the extruder.   
x_carriage: There's a provision for an endstop adjustment screw.  Use a 3 mm tap to form threads.  Get a spring from a retractable ballpoint pen and cut it in half.  Use it to apply a bit of tension to the adjustment bolt.  Save the other half of the spring.  
x_ends:  String zip-ties from the back and secure the X rods into the U-grooves.  Make it tight so the rods seat well in the groove.  It's okay if the rods can slide, as long as they're not too loose.  Use ties to attach LM8UU bearings to the front pieces and drop 5 mm nuts  into the well for Z axis threaded rods.  There should be some float in the nut wells to minimize Z axis wobble.  Use a needle file to clear out the cavity if needed.  
For the motor mount side, use 2 mm nuts and bolts to secure an endstop switch for the X axis limit.  The motor mount holes are slotted so adjust belt tension there.  Use a 3 mm tap to thread the Z stop bolt hole and use the other half of the spring to apply tension to the stop bolt.  
On the idler end, break off the support material in the idler bolt hole or drill it out with a 5 mm bit.  Use two 5 x 10 x 4 mm bearings and a 5 x 18 mm bolt and nut for the idler.  I had some .5 mm spacers for RC cars so I used one between the bearings and another against the bearing and the top half of the X end.  Print some spacers out if you don't have them lying around.  
z_support:  Use 3 mm nuts and bolts to clamp and 2.5 x 12 mm screws to attach to the frame.

comments.text: I have printed the x-ends and noticed something that i never knew. I have the acrylic (black) HICTOP version. I have completed the Prusa i3 Rework for the print bed with no issues-however my printer came stock with 8mm threaded rods and smooth rods (as measured by caliper on the outside of the threaded rod teeth, not sure if this is correct way to measure). Also, the distance between the threaded rod and the smooth rod is completely different. Does anyone have any suggestions other than printing the z-top/bottoms from the rework kit, drill new mounting holes for said brackets, and mount on my existing acrylic (black) hictop frame?
comments.author: morris4019

comments.text: You wouldn't be able to use my x-ends with 8mm threaded rods.  The design captures a 5mm nut.  But since the distance between the threaded and smooth rod is greater on your printer, maybe you could design a "clip" of sorts to fit in the nut cage and interface with the 8mm threaded rod?
comments.author: morris4019

thanks for this design, i made one , it is much better than the equivalent parts I purchased. your attention to detail and precision is evident when assembling. Everything is well thought out, has a purpose and works as designed.
It prints easily and quickly. Thanks very much keep up the good work.
comments.author: jasjodi

comments.text: Thanks for the comment.
comments.author: jasjodi

comments.text: I've noticed on my i3 that the nozzle is set up great for 3 movement directions, but when moving the Y bed front-to-back, if anything catches on the nozzle, the nozzle is drawn downwards, which can cause head crashes. So, how to make it as rigid as possible? I'm trying a little reinforcement for the nozzle near the bottom rod. Even so, with my current, mostly original set of parts, as I move the carriage around I feel play in the LM8UU bearings plus some play in the x gantry, mainly around the Z bearing holders. It looks like your parts may be better than these original parts in this area. I assume zip ties will have less play compared to these cut-cylinder PLA bearing holders. I also need to look at better bearings and rods. For now I'll try using PLA bushings + PTFE lube on the X axis in place of these choppy LM8UUs.
comments.author: thinkyhead

comments.text: I found the same issue with the original design.  In my case, beside the loose grip the plastic had on the LM8UU bearings, the X carriage "twisted" a bit.  The original X carriage design has the top bearing to one side.  This allowed the extruder to pull away at the top.  I moved the top bearing on the carriage to the center and that helped quite a bit.  I also adjusted the position of the extruder's mount.  As for play in the bearing itself, I haven't had that issue.  Perhaps you may have knocked a few balls out of the bearings?
comments.author: thinkyhead

comments.text: you need bearing on top of z threaded rod
comments.author: how_eee

comments.text: This is terrible advice, please don't ever give it again.  You want the threaded rods to float so that they aren't influencing X/Y movement of the extruder.  If you overconstrain the rods, you'll exhibit what is known as "z wobble".
comments.author: how_eee

comments.text: There's noticeably more Z wobble in the prints with the bearings than without. For the time being, I have them out.  I need to find straighter threaded rods.  I tried straightening the ones I have best as I could, but I think I just need to start with straight rods.
comments.author: how_eee

comments.text: Nice slim design. Can't quite see how the extruder attaches to the x-carriage - could you put up some photos showing this please?
comments.author: Wired1

comments.text: One of the photos show the extruder off the carriage.  Two 3 x 50 mm bolts join them.
